label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, October 1, 1942
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, discussing their work, how she could possibly join them in Hawaii, and Morris’s work success. Sidney continues in his letter to reminisce on time they had spent with their beloved dog, Clippy, lament over how much coffee and Coca-cola the officers in his office drink, and describing their meals.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
II
October 1, 1942
Gertle Darling, 
Thank you so much for the ear drums. They are wonderful
and just what I wanted. I wore them yesterday with rubber fins on
my feet and thought the government would seize and put me in their
stock pile of rubber. Have you ever tried those swimming fins. They
are marvellous andone goes as fast as a motor boat with them on.
Swimming the regular way it takes me about an hour to go out to
a buoy that is not more than fifty yards from the shore but with
them on I get there before I can take my breath.
I have just finished the most wonderful "round about" that
you have ever known. I was sent out by my captain to obtain something
and started asking at the bottom and then gradually went to the
captain at the top. He in turn referrred me to the man below him so
that at thex end of four hours I had made the complete circle of
twelve men and was right back at where I had started without
obtaining the thlng I set out for. Hwever it did not bother me
at all. I figured I had done my best and if no one wanted to
make a decision or try to help there was nothing that I could do.
However one man did give me excellent advice. He said "go back
and get someone with eagles on their collars [to make the request] and you will get some
where." I think he had the secret.
Morris and I worked until ten thirty last night arranging
files and winding up a mass of correspondence. My feet really
hurt by the time I got home. It is so slow driving at night wit_h
the faint black out lamps[,] as you can not see your hand in front
of your face and have to creep along. It is impossible to
distinguish anyone walking along the street until you are on t[op of them]
[End Page 1]
You asked me in one of your letters what chance there
was of your comming out here. I have enquired everywhere and the
only way that I can find out is for you to pass a civil service 
exam and apply for a civil service job. Then you ask for duty ln
in the Hawaiin islands and by the time you are given it I will be
in some other post. I really think I will be sent home or to another
post before you arrive here. Also there is nothing as iteresting
in the way of a job as you have or xxxxxxx any job that has the
future possibilities of travel that you have now. You know how
we have always said that lt is impossible to tell what the future
holds and that when you try to make plans they never come out.
I think this may be the case now. With the uncertainity of everything
I believe that our chances of comming together in the near future
will be better if we do not try to make arran gments and tie ourselves
up with naval contracts to work and civil service arrangements.
Morris played tennis yesterday but I was to tired and just
wnet for a short swim andthenstretched out on my bed. In a little
while the old man came in so pouped that he could hardly talk, and 
croaked that I should force brandy down histhroat. However I let
him lie there and waited to collect hisinsruance . He pulled through
somehowand is rushing around again today doing big things and giving
all the yeoman hell because the desks are not dusted or because there
are mistakes in the letters. If he does not end up a captain I will
be very much suprised because he is the most efficent person I have
ever seen. when this war isover I am going to put you and Morris
working for me[,] and while I lie in a hammock you too can win a great
fortune on which I will live in luxury. By now I am sure you
talk in crisp short sentences, and utter commands in a stacacco
voice. What I wish you would tell me at your earliest
[End Page 2]
convenience dear madam is, do people jump to their feet when 
you address them, and are your orders law[?] I would give anything to
walk into your office nqw and see you . It would be such fun to
laugh about our business abilities again and than to go out and eat
much to much lunch und loaf through the afternoon. I love Sundays
so, because I can lie on the beach and let the sun pour down on my
back with never the thought of the morrow. Do you remember
how in Seal Harbor we use to lie on the wooden platform of the
club and sun bathe in a semi stupor. You loved it like a cat and
I couldhardly get you to come and eat those wonderful lunches that
the negroes use to cookd for us. Then we would walk to Jordans
pond and stuff ourselves on popoevers and give Clippy little
pieces to make him fat and I use to call him a fat pig. How happy
we were. Andfortunately it doesn not seam at all long ago. I
seem recently to be able to push time back so that everything that  
we did together was only ye_sterday. As a resutxt it makes the
time we have been seperated seem like nothing compared to what it
might be if I counted the days, weeks and months. I remember so
clearly all the conversations we had togehter and the things we
we have done during our thirteen years of married life, and I thank
God for these happy memories because they are such a comfort to me
now.
I have just been appointed treasurer forthe coffee and
Coca cola mess and expect to lose my shirt. Why the officers have
to have coffee brewing all the time isquite beyond me. I think it
only-takes them away from their work, as they are always getting
up for a cup of coffee or a coca cola and must take at least ten
[End Page 3]
minutes for each drink. Nevertheless it appearsto be an old
navy custom and one that they will not break.
We had dinner at the wagon wheel[,] a little resturant
near our hotel last night. We both ordered fruit salad as our main
course and it was wonderu l. Big slices of pinapple, paupaya,
and other native fruits. It was served ice cold and could not have
been a more delicious hot weather dish. Get Rose to make it
for you some time. It is a dry sald , no juices or sugar, and you
must have it in a heaping bowl. Yesterday for lu[n]ch at the bachelor
officers quarters we had Ricestaffel. Wonderful. Heaping mounds of
rice with all sorts of goodies on top. A man was ther[e] who had been
in [S]ingapore xxxx during the attack and he was most interesting.
It is fascinating when you talk to the ones that have been in the
battles and deadly dull when you read long treatises on ballistics[,]
or something equally dull.
I off again to see a man about obtaining transportation
forthe office and guess I till see fifty before I am through.
I send you all my love dear and a great big hug and kiss.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 4]
